content.definition: An extremely rare mosaic overgrowth disorder caused by somatic activating mutations in AKT1, characterized by progressive, asymmetric, and disproportionate overgrowth of multiple tissues including bone, skin, connective tissue, and vascular structures. Named after the Greek god Proteus who could change shape.

cutaneous: Cerebriform connective tissue nevi (soles of feet)

pathophysiology.etiology: Somatic activating mutation in AKT1 (c.49G>A, p.Glu17Lys)
pathophysiology.inheritance: Sporadic (somatic mosaicism - constitutional mutation would be lethal)
pathophysiology.timing: Overgrowth is minimal at birth, becomes progressive

diagnosis.criteria: Established diagnostic criteria require specific combinations of features
diagnosis.genetic: Detection of AKT1 mutation in affected tissue

surveillance: DVT/PE prevention and monitoring (major mortality cause)
surgical: Amputation rarely needed for severe overgrowth

prognosis.life_threatening: DVT/PE is major cause of premature mortality
prognosis.progressive: Overgrowth continues through childhood, may stabilize

learning_objectives: Recognize pathognomonic cerebriform connective tissue nevus
Understand AKT1 mutation and its effects
Know DVT/PE is major mortality cause
clinical_pearls: Cerebriform connective tissue nevus (soles) is PATHOGNOMONIC
Overgrowth is minimal at birth - becomes progressive
DVT/PE is leading cause of death - thromboprophylaxis essential
Joseph Merrick ('Elephant Man') likely had Proteus syndrome, not neurofibromatosis
